status_message:
Still looking for a good fall internship? The Rutgers Office of Media Relations has great internship opportunities for students who can shoot and edit their own videos. Our interns' work has been viewed by as many as 10,000 people a day – giving interns many clips for their resumes.

We seek undergraduate or graduate students for two separate for-credit internships for the Fall 2013 semester. Candidates MUST have experience shooting and editing their own videos, specifically using the Final Cut Pro editing program. 

**Applicants for both positions must have strong writing skills as students may also be contributing to our social media projects. Experience using online content management systems is a strong plus. 

Requirements: Candidates should be highly motivated and qualified juniors, seniors, or grad students. They must be able to work independently. If you meet our requirements, please send a cover letter, resume, and two multimedia samples (YouTube links are acceptable) by e-mail to Karen Smith, assistant director of new and emerging media, at ksmith@ur.rutgers.edu. Your subject line should say: Internship. 

Please visit Rutgers Today (http://rutgerstoday.rutgers.edu) and the Rutgers Today You Tube page (http://www.youtube.com/rutgerstoday) to learn more about our program.

*Candidates should negotiate credit-bearing internships directly with their academic departments or Career Services.
link_name: http://rutgerstoday.rutgers.edu/

status_message: Rutgers President Robert L. Barchi accepts Tim Pernetti's resignation.
link_name: Statement of President Barchi Regarding Tim Pernetti | Office of the President

status_message:
Here is the Text of the president's statement:

STATEMENT BY RUTGERS UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT ROBERT L. BARCHI REGARDING MIKE RICE

Rutgers University has a long and proud history as one of the nation's most diverse and welcoming academic institutions. Coach Rice's abusive language and actions are deeply offensive and egregiously violate the university's core values. 

When video excerpts of basketball practices were reviewed last fall by Athletic Director Tim Pernetti, he immediately notified me and sought the advice of internal and outside counsel.  The university hired an independent investigator to look into this matter thoroughly. Based on the external investigator's findings and recommendations, Tim and I agreed that Coach Rice should be suspended, penalized $75,000 in fines and lost salary, ordered to undergo anger management counseling, and put on notice that his behavior would be closely monitored. Tim Pernetti also made it clear to Coach Rice that there would be zero tolerance for additional infractions. Tim kept me fully apprised and I supported his actions.

 Yesterday, I personally reviewed the video evidence, which shows a chronic and pervasive pattern of disturbing behavior. I have now reached the conclusion that Coach Rice cannot continue to serve effectively in a position that demands the highest levels of leadership, responsibility and public accountability. He cannot continue to coach at Rutgers University. Therefore, Tim Pernetti and I have jointly decided to terminate Mike Rice's employment at Rutgers.
President Robert L. Barchi and Athletic Director Tim Pernetti announced this morning that Mike Rice will not continue to coach at Rutgers. Read the president's statement.
link_name: Statement by Rutgers University President Robert L. Barchi Regarding Mike Rice

status_message:
In case you missed it, Rutgers is looking to clinch the first outright BIG EAST CHAMPIONSHIP in school history on Thursday! Here are some details on parking - review it now so you're ready for Thursday.

Due to the Rutgers vs. Louisville football game on Thursday, November 29, heavy traffic is expected on the Busch and Livingston campuses by mid-afternoon.  

The following parking lot closures and changes are effective for that day:

The Stadium West Lot will be closed the entire day. All Busch commuter students with Zone B parking permits will be allowed to park on the Livingston Campus (Yellow Lot).
Lots 48, 53A, 59, 60A, 60B, 64, 67 and 67B will close at 2pm to faculty, staff, and residents. Those already parked in the lots will not be forced to move their cars at that time. Drivers may exit the lots without restrictions after 2pm.

People are urged to take advantage of the Rutgers transit system and not drive on game day, if at all possible. Plan ahead and leave extra time for traveling between campuses for meetings and classes. Those going to the stadium, should try to get there as early as possible to avoid the rush and crowds.

Regularly scheduled and football season bus service will be in effect on November 29.

Buses from College Avenue will discharge passengers at Johnson Park for the short walk to the stadium. Service will also be provided from the Louis Brown Athletic Center (RAC) General Football Parking Area on the Livingston campus to the Rutgers Stadium. These special shuttles will begin three hours prior to the game.

Contact info@aps.rutgers.edu for any questions or additional information.

link_name: Rutgers Resident Knights

status_message:
IMPORTANT: Students who continue to struggle in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy should read through this entire post to learn more about your options for your grades and credits this semester.

We have heard from many members of the Rutgers community that significant numbers of students continue to struggle in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy.  Homes and communities have been damaged or destroyed, power and water services have been disrupted, fuel supplies have been restricted, and, most tragically, scores of people have died.  Many of you live in areas that continue to be affected by the storm and its aftermath, which has made it difficult for you to prepare for and to attend classes or to complete your assignments.  

For those of you who have experienced hardships in the wake of Hurricane Sandy, we urge you to avail yourselves of the academic assistance that is always available for our students.  Take advantage of academic support services, including those within your department or School, and make appointments to visit your professors to talk about issues you are having.  Discuss with them the possibility of making up work, acquiring additional time for assignments, and, as a last resort and only in instances of real hardship, arranging for a temporary grade that will permit you to complete your coursework during the winter recess.  Please note that the final recourse with each of these remedies is up to individual faculty members, but we urge you to communicate with all of your professors about any distress you are suffering as a result of the hurricane.  Like you, our faculty members have experienced the effects of this historic natural disaster, and most are eager to assist you during this difficult time.  

Because so many students have contacted us with concerns that hurricane-related hardships are affecting their GPA and academic performance, Rutgers is implementing a one-time policy that will allow undergraduate and pre-professional students adversely impacted by the hurricane to have their Fall 2012 course grades converted to Pass/No Credit ("Pass" is a grade of C or better).  If, after exhausting all of the options available for academic support, you feel that you cannot do your work because you continue to be affected in the storm's aftermath, you can go online and fill out a Grade Conversion Application: https://sakai.rutgers.edu/convertpf.jsp .  In the application, you will be asked to describe briefly the hardships you have experienced that are directly related to Hurricane Sandy and that continue to have a significant impact on your academic progress during this semester.  Should you choose to have ALL of your grades for the Fall semester 2012 converted to Pass/No credit (you cannot select individual courses for the grade conversion), you will need to complete the Grade Conversion Application before midnight on Monday, November 19, 2012.  If you do choose this option and complete the online application, you cannot reverse your decision later.

Please note that this option should not be taken lightly.  You should first consult with academic counselors in your department or School to understand the full ramifications of such a decision for your particular academic major or career path.  For example, in some cases, courses without an assigned letter grade can negatively affect applications to some professional programs and graduate schools.  If you opt for the grade conversion, however, a footnote on your transcript for Fall 2012 will reflect that the grade conversion was part of a University-wide program for students adversely impacted by Hurricane Sandy in Fall 2012.  Nevertheless, some programs, including law schools, treat grades of P as equivalent to C.  In addition, a conversion to Pass/No Credit may adversely affect students who are on financial aid probation.

This program is designed to be confidential with respect to the decision you make about using the Pass/No Credit option.  If you choose the option of a Grade Conversion, you are not obligated to share your decision with anyone, including your professors.  Note that if you opt to convert your grades and you additionally take a temporary grade, your final grade, after you make up that temporary grade, will also convert to Pass/No Credit.  

As President Barchi stressed this week, this has been an extremely challenging time for so many people in New Jersey and in the tri-state area.  But the storm and its aftermath have also shown that the Rutgers community is resilient, and we will continue to work together through this difficult period.
link_name: https://sakai.rutgers.edu/convertpf.jsp

Happy Election Day! Don't forget to get out and vote. A reminder on two changes to polling locations for the Rutgers-New Brunswick/Piscataway campuses:

Voting in the City of New Brunswick Ward 1, District 6 has been relocated from Labor Education Center to the Woodrow Wilson School (133 Tunison Road, New Brunswick - within the Rutgers Village Section).

Voting in the Township of Piscataway Ward 4, District 6 has been relocated from the Livingston Recreation Center to the Livingston Student Center (84 Joyce Kilmer Avenue, Piscataway).

Questions relating to polling and polling locations should be directed to the New Jersey Division of Elections at: http://www.njelections.org/.

status_message:
Rutgers has been advised by PSE&G that electrical service will be turned off on the Cook/Douglass Campus from 10 a.m. until 1 p.m. on Tuesday, November 6, 2012. This will include all classroom and office buildings with the exception of ASB II, ASB III, Douglass Developmental Disabilities Center, Federation Hall, and the Labor Education Center. Additionally, all residence halls and apartments on the Cook/Douglass Campus will be affected with the exception of Old Gibbons, Helyar House, and Henderson Apartments.

As a result, classes on the Cook/Douglass Campus will be cancelled for periods 1 through 3 (or between 9:00 AM and 1:55 PM) on the Cook/Douglass Campus on Tuesday, November 6, 2012.

Staff members in affected buildings on the Cook/Douglass Campus must coordinate the potential impact of the electrical outage on their work schedule and assignments with their individual supervisors prior to the end of today's workday, if possible, or prior to the start of the power outage tomorrow.  The interruption of electrical services will not extend the work hours of any University staff member.

Housing and Residence Life staff will notify residential students regarding potential impacts.
Rutgers President Robert Barchi says he's proud of the Rutgers community for the way it handled the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy. Take a look:

Voting in the Township of Piscataway Ward 4, District 6 has been relocated from the Livingston Recreation Center to the Livingston Student Center (84 Joyce Kilmer Avenue, Piscataway).

status_message:
University Status Update
Thursday, November 1, 2012
4:00 p.m.
 
Below is an update of conditions on the New Brunswick/Piscataway, Newark
and Camden campuses of Rutgers University in the aftermath of Hurricane
Sandy.

Status of the New Brunswick/Piscataway Campus

Classes:
.        All classes across the New Brunswick/Piscataway Campus are
cancelled through Sunday, November 4, 2012. Classes will resume in New
Brunswick/Piscataway on Monday, November 5, 2012.

Registration:
.        Registration for spring classes for current New
Brunswick/Piscataway students has been postponed until Sunday, November
11, 2012.

Residence Halls:
.        As of 7:00 p.m. on Thursday, November 1, 2012, all residence halls
on the New Brunswick/Piscataway Campus will be open with the following
exceptions:
        o        Rockoff Hall
        o        Helyar House
        o        Henderson Apartments
        o        Old Gibbons Complex

Despite this improvement, the university continues to urge any students
residing on the New Brunswick/Piscataway Campus to return home, if they
can do so safely, and remain at home until classes resume.

Dining Services:
.        Dining halls remain open on the Busch and Livingston campuses.

.        The dining hall at Brower Commons on the College Avenue Campus
will reopen at 4:00 p.m. on Sunday, November 4, 2012. Neilson Dining Hall,
which serves the Cook/Douglass campuses, also will reopen at 4:00 p.m. on
Sunday, November 4, 2012.

.        The university continues to provide bus service between New
Brunswick and the Busch/Livingston campuses so that students will have
full access to dining services.

Power/Water Service:
.        Water service has been restored throughout the City of New
Brunswick.

.        Power service has been restored to the College Avenue Campus in
New Brunswick.

.        Power service has been restored to most of the Cook/Douglass
Campus in New Brunswick.

.        Power and water service remain operational on the Busch and
Livingston campuses in Piscataway.

Administrative Offices:
.        Normal operating conditions have resumed for all employees in
offices on the New Brunswick/Piscataway Campus. Employees working in
offices who can return to work are instructed to do so, in accordance with
their normal work schedules. Employees with questions are encouraged to
contact their supervisors.

Status of the Camden Campus

.        The Camden Campus is fully operational and classes have resumed.

.        Registration for spring classes for current students on the Camden
Campus will proceed as previously scheduled on Sunday, November 4, 2012.

Status of the Newark Campus

.        All classes across the Newark Campus are cancelled through Sunday,
November 4, 2012. Classes resume in Newark on Monday, November 5, 2012.

.        Registration for spring classes for current Newark students has
been postponed until Sunday, November 11, 2012.

.        Power has been restored to approximately 95 percent of the Newark
Campus.

.        Residence and dining halls are open on the Newark Campus.

.        Normal operating conditions have resumed for all employees on the
Newark Campus. Employees working in offices who can return to work are
instructed to do so, in accordance with their normal work schedules.
Employees with questions are encouraged to contact their supervisors.

For the latest information, please refer to the appropriate "Campus
Operating Status" web page, which can be found at: www.rutgers.edu.
link_name: Welcome | Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

status_message: Registration for currently enrolled students on the New Brunswick and Newark campuses has been postponed until November 11. Registration on the Camden Campus will proceed as previously scheduled on November 4.
For those who asked about Saturday classes: All classes are canceled through Sunday on the Newark and New Brunswick campuses.

University Status Update
October 31, 2012
5:00 p.m.

Below is an update of conditions on the New Brunswick/Piscataway, Newark and Camden campuses of Rutgers University in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy.

Status of the New Brunswick/Piscataway Campus

Classes:

* All classes across the New Brunswick/Piscataway Campus are cancelled through Sunday, November 4, 2012. Classes will resume in New Brunswick/Piscataway on Monday, November 5, 2012.

Power/Water Service:

* Water service has been restored throughout the City of New Brunswick.

* Power service has been restored to the College Avenue Campus in New Brunswick.

* Officials expect power to be available on the Cook/Douglass campuses in New Brunswick on the morning of Thursday, November 1, 2012.

* Power and water service remain operational on the Busch and Livingston campuses in Piscataway.

Residence Halls:

* Residence halls remain open on the Busch and Livingston campuses.

* Residence halls will reopen on the College Avenue Campus at 7:00 p.m. tonight, October 31, 2012.

* Residence halls remain closed on the Cook/Douglass campuses until fire systems can be checked. Temporary student housing remains available at the Busch and Livingston student centers.

  
Despite these improvements, the university continues to urge any students residing on the New Brunswick/Piscataway Campus to return home, if they can do so safely, until classes resume.

Dining Services:

* Dining halls remain open on the Busch and Livingston campuses.

* The dining hall at Brower Commons on the College Avenue Campus will reopen at 4:00 p.m. on Sunday, November 4, 2012. Until then, the university will provide additional bus service between the College Avenue Campus and the Busch/Livingston campuses so that students will have full access to dining services.

* Neilson Dining Hall, which serves the Cook/Douglass campuses, will reopen at 4:00 p.m. on Sunday, November 4, 2012.

Administrative Offices:

* Normal operating conditions resume for all employees in offices on the New Brunswick/Piscataway Campus effective 5:00 p.m. today, October 31, 2012. Employees working in offices who can return to work are instructed to do so, in accordance with their normal work schedules. Employees with questions are encouraged to contact their supervisors.

  
Status of the Camden Campus

* All classes resume on the Camden Campus on Thursday, November 1, 2012.

* Normal operating conditions for all employees on the Camden Campus resume effective 5:00 p.m. today, Wednesday, October 31, 2012. Employees who can return to work are instructed to do so, in accordance with their normal work schedules. Employees with questions are encouraged to contact their supervisors.

Status of the Newark Campus

* All classes across the Newark Campus are cancelled through Sunday, November 4, 2012. Classes resume in Newark on Monday, November 5, 2012.

* Power has been restored to approximately 95 percent of the Newark Campus.

* Residence and dining halls are open on the Newark Campus.

* Normal operating conditions for all employees on the Newark Campus resume effective 5:00 today, Wednesday, October 31, 2012. Employees who can return to work are instructed to do so, in accordance with their normal work schedules.
Employees with questions are encouraged to contact their supervisors.

For the latest information, please refer to the appropriate "Campus Operating Status" web page, which can be found at: www.rutgers.edu .
link_name: Welcome | Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

status_message:
Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
Campus Status Update
October 30, 2012
5:00 p.m.

Officials at Rutgers are continuing to monitor conditions on our New
Brunswick, Newark and Camden campuses and throughout the region in the
aftermath of Hurricane Sandy.  The impact of the storm has been described
by State and public safety officials as unprecedented.

During the height of the storm, the electrical infrastructure throughout
the region sustained major damage.  Widespread power outages continue,
which are significantly affecting campus operations, as well as the lives
of our students, faculty, staff and their families.  Public transportation
in parts of New Jersey is compromised due to flooding and electrical
problems.  In New Brunswick, the public water supply has also been
affected.

After personally assessing conditions on the Rutgers campuses in New
Brunswick and Piscataway, and consulting with the Chancellors of our
campuses in Newark and Camden, President Barchi has determined that the
conditions vary among the three campuses.  The impact of the storm on the
New Brunswick and Newark campuses is much more severe than the damage
sustained in Camden.

Therefore, all daytime and evening classes on the New Brunswick and Newark
campuses are cancelled through Friday, November 2, 2012.  Classes on the
New Brunswick and Newark campuses will resume Monday, November 5, 2012.

Classes on the Camden campus are cancelled Wednesday, October 31 only. 
Classes on the Rutgers-Camden campus are scheduled to resume Thursday,
November 1, 2012.  Rutgers-Camden students should check the Rutgers-Camden
website for additional information.

President Barchi has also extended the closure of offices and the
cancellation of programs on all campuses of Rutgers University, through
5:00 p.m. Wednesday, October 31.  Employees critical to operations, and to
the health and safety of our campus community, will still report to work
as specified by their supervisor.  Normal operating conditions resume for
all employees at 5:00 p.m. on Wednesday, October 31.

In New Brunswick, storm damage caused the failure of the New Brunswick
Water pumping system, which has resulted in a critical loss of water
throughout the city. The university has been advised by New Brunswick
Authorities that the water system cannot sustain domestic and fire
protection needs.

Therefore, Public Safety and Residence Life authorities are requesting
that any students on our New Brunswick and Piscataway campuses who can
safely return to their homes do so at this time.  We have been advised by
County Emergency Management authorities that all major roadways are open
at this time.  Any student who is unable to leave the campus will be
relocated to Residence Halls within the Township of Piscataway where the
water system has remained unaffected.

Public safety officials are currently in the process of relocating
students and we ask that you contact your residence hall adviser for
instructions regarding relocation from your residence hall.  While we
regret the inconvenience of these actions, they are necessary to ensure
the health and safety of our students.

For the latest information, please refer to the appropriate "Campus
Operating Status" web page, which can be found at: www.rutgers.edu.
Update: there is a water boil advisory for New Brunswick.
link_name: New Brunswick City Government

status_message:
IMPORTANT UPDATE: Officials at Rutgers continue to monitor the storm pattern of Hurricane Sandy.  Due to the continuing threat of flooding and high winds, President Barchi has extended the closure of offices and the cancellation of programs on all campuses of Rutgers University, through 5:00 p.m. Tuesday, October 30.  Employees critical to operations, and the health and safety of our campus community, will still report to work as specified by their supervisor.

Daytime and evening classes on all Rutgers campuses remain cancelled for Tuesday, October 30th. Classes are scheduled to resume on Wednesday, October 31.

IMPORTANT UPDATE: Officials at Rutgers have been closely monitoring the storm pattern of Hurricane Sandy.  Due to the increased threat of flooding and high winds, President Barchi has ordered the closure of offices and programs on all campuses of Rutgers University, effective Noon on Monday, October 29, until 12:01 a.m. on Tuesday, October 30.  Employees critical to operations, and the health and safety of our campus community, will still report to work as specified by their supervisor. 

Daytime and evening classes on all Rutgers campuses remain cancelled on Monday, October 29, and Tuesday, October 30. Classes are scheduled to resume on Wednesday, October 31.

status_message: Worried about power outages and Rutgers' Early Action due date? Don't be. We've extended the application due date to 11/08/12

Weather update: As you are aware, in anticipation of Hurricane Sandy, New Brunswick Mayor James Cahill declared a State of Emergency and imposed restriction on travel along City streets for non-emergency personnel effective Monday morning. However, we have been advised that this restriction will not apply to Rutgers employees. All Rutgers employees with a valid Rutgers identification card will be allowed to travel to and from work.
Update: Daytime and evening classes on the Newark, New Brunswick, and Camden campuses are canceled for Monday, October 29 and Tuesday, October 30.
Update: Classes are now canceled on the Camden campus for both Monday and Tuesday.

Daytime and evening classes on the New Brunswick and Piscataway Campuses are canceled for Monday, October 29 and Tuesday, October 30. Classes will resume on Wednesday, October 31. Classes are canceled on the Camden Campus for Monday as well. Visit the campus websites for further details.
We have received many questions about classes. We are monitoring the situation closely and will have an update shortly. Once again, the safety of our students is our top priority.

The safety of our students is our first priority. Visit our website for the latest campus status information for all of our campuses. To help you prepare for the anticipated impacts of Hurricane Sandy, we offer the following list of precautions: 
• You will be safer in your residence hall room, apartment or home than on the road or outside on campus.
• During high winds it is not safe to venture outside since flying debris can be deadly.
• Sheltering-in-place is often the safest course of action for individuals who are not in a storm surge or flood-prone area.
• Because of hazardous weather and road conditions, you can help keep the roads clear for emergency workers, and for those who may have to evacuate due to danger in their area.
• Close windows and doors in your room or apartment during the storm. Stay away from glass pane windows. Interior rooms provide better protection.
• Hurricanes can have a "lull" so don't assume the storm is over until you have confirmation from a reliable news source.
• If you have a refrigerator turn it to the coldest setting and keep it closed as much as possible so that food will last longer if the power goes out.
• Make sure you know the evacuation route within your building.
• Make sure your cell phone is fully charged.
• You should carry family contact information with you during the storm.
• Stay alert for extended rainfall and subsequent flooding even after a hurricane or tropical storm has ended.
• Drive only if necessary and avoid flooded roads and washed-out bridges.
• Keep away from loose or dangling power lines and report them immediately.
• Stay out of any building that has water around it.
• Avoid the use of candles if you lose power.
• If you have a flashlight keep it somewhere easily accessible to you. 
• Avoid drinking or preparing food with tap water until you are sure it's not contaminated.
• Check refrigerated food for spoilage. If in doubt, throw it out.
• Use the telephone only for emergency calls.
• Depending on your residence, ensure that outdoor trash cans, potted plants, bikes and other loose object are secured or moved inside -- if possible to keep them from becoming projectiles in the wind. If not, make sure these items are secured.
• Remember that text messages can often get around network disruptions when a phone call might not be able to get through.
• Please remember to cooperate fully with public safety, other university staff, and local officials during the storm.
• Continue to monitor the Campus Status Page athttp://campusstatus.rutgers.edu/ for the latest updates. You can also contact the RU-info Call Center at 732-445-info (4636), tune in to RU-info Channel - RU-tv Channel 3 on campus, or text RUTGERS to 66746. Please do not call the Rutgers Police for campus status information.
link_name: Welcome | Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

status_message:
Please see the information below regarding the situation on the Newark Campus:

Last night, Tuesday, Feb. 7, Rutgers-Newark campus police received information from University of South Dakota authorities that led them to search the room of a Rutgers-Newark student. This operation was conducted along with the Essex County Bomb Squad and the Newark Police Special Operations Division. The teams found potentially dangerous materials in the student's room and removed the materials. Subsequently students from University Square, Woodward Hall and Talbott Hall were evacuated. 

The student whose room contained potentially dangerous materials was arrested on multiple charges.  Another evacuation of University Square was ordered a short while ago. The FBI is now involved with this matter. FBI officials informed Rutgers-Newark today that a potentially hazardous substance that would not have been detected by the squads last night should be further investigated. 

The Rutgers University Police are handling this situation with the well being and safety of everyone in the campus community foremost in mind. Further information will be given as it becomes available.

status_message:
There are some false rumors and misconceptions about the future of the Grease Trucks. Here's what really happening: There's no plan to eliminate the Grease Truck lot. The university wants to develop a process that serves our students, treats vendors fairly and ensures that we are operating in a cost-effective manner. The university provides security, electricity and waste removal for the Grease Truck lot and the cost of these services is more than the university receives in rent.

The university will seek the input of our students before we determine what food options should go into that location.

The university wants to handle the Grease Truck lot in the much the same way it deals with the food courts in the student centers. Food vendors who are interested in doing business at that location should have the opportunity to compete for available spots and the current vendors are welcome to submit a bid.

status_message: As Rutgers student Chris Jones sat in the studio audience of Anderson Cooper's CNN special on bullying, which was taped at Rutgers on Wednesday, he wanted to console children who told their stories on stage. Their experiences were painfully familiar to him. "I wanted to hug them and tell them, 'I know where you're coming from,'' said Jones. "I wanted to tell them that really, it does get better.'' status_message: WeatherWatcher is doing a good job of updating weather info related to the storm. A great group of students helping to keep the Rutgers community informed.

In the aftermath of Irene, travel around the Rutgers-New Brunswick campus is likely to be restricted on Mon., 8/29 due to flooding and road closures. We therefore advise any students who have not yet moved into their residence halls to check the status of the roads in the areas around campus before attempting to move in on Mon. If they are unable to move in Mon., they should do so on either Tues. or Wed., 8/30 or 31.

Classes are not scheduled to begin until Thurs., 9/1.

The Rutgers-New Brunswick Campus is serving as an evacuation center for several hundred New Jersey residents forced from their homes by Hurricane Irene. They are our guests and the university is providing them with food and shelter at this difficult time.
Hi Anayia. Classes start Thurs., Sept. 1. Check out the academic calendar.
